name: 陳雅玫
objective: This is an introductory course aiming to familiarize students with basic concepts of translation, including qualifications of good translators, the procedure of translation, use of references & electronic tools and the idea of translation equivalence. Also, the relevance of contrastive studies between English and Chinese to translation will be introduced. A guided application of the linguistic knowledge to practical work will be provided, in the interest of assisting students in formulating suitable and appropriate translation strategies and techniques. This course is intended to prepare students for more specialized translation training.
schedule:
Week 1: course introduction
Week 2: lecture on “what makes a good translator?”; exercises
Week 3: oral report; lecture on: (1) procedure of translation;
(2)  references & electrical tools
Week 4: oral report; lecture on translation equivalence
Week 5: oral report; lecture on contrastive studies of lexicon & translation (1)
Week 6: oral report; lecture on contrastive studies of lexicon & translation (2)
Week 7: oral report; lecture on contrastive studies of verbs &
translation
Week 8: oral report; lecture on contrastive studies of nouns and pronouns & translation
Week 9: Mid-term exam
Week 10: oral report; lecture on contrastive studies of prepositions and articles & translation 
Week 11: oral report; lecture on contrastive studies of adjectives and adverbs & translation 
Week 12: oral report ; lecture on contrastive of conjunctions and negative constructions & translation
Week 13: oral report; lecture on contrastive studies of word order & translation (1)
Week 14: oral report; lecture on contrastive studies of word order &
translation (2)
Week 15: oral report; lecture on idioms & translation
Week 16: oral report; lecture on cultures & translation
Week 17: wrap up
Week 18: Final exam

Requirements & Rules:
1. Please turn off your cell phone during the two-hour class period.

2. Absence: Students are expected to attend the class ON TIME. 
(1) Being late for more than TWENTY minutes equals one hour unexcused absence. One hour UNEXCUSED absence results in 2 points deduction, whereas one hour EXCUSED absence results in 1 point deduction.  
(2) For an absence to be excused, students need to submit compelling evidence of the gravity or unforseeability of the event causing the absence within ONE WEEK. 
(3) Students missing more than TEN hours excused or unexcused will have a fail.
(4) Absence from a class is no excuse for not knowing the assignment and what has been discussed in that class. There will be NO MAKE-UP EXAM unless you have valid and official reasons for absence BEFOREHAND.

3. Assignment: 
  (1) Translation assignments will be given periodically throughout the course. All translation assignments have to be typed. Further details concerning the format will be provided in WEEK 3. 
(2) Each assignment goes through the following stages: (a) submission of the first draft by due date, (b) discussion of assignment in class, and (c) submission of the second draft, which will be evaluated. 
(3) All assignments must be submitted via e-mail by 5pm Saturday. For late assignments, 20% of the assignment mark will be deducted each day. Assignments more than THREE days late will not be accepted

4. Pre-readings and PowerPoint presentations
(1) All students are expected to complete the assigned pre-readings before classes. All articles covered by the pre-readings are included for the mid-term or final exams.
(2) Students will be divided into several groups. Each group (around 3-4 persons) takes turns making PowerPoint presentations of the articles covered by the pre-readings. 
(3) Guidelines for the oral reports are given below: 
(a) PowerPoint presentations must be made in ENGLISH.
(b) E-mail the PowerPoint slides to the instructor by 5 pm Sunady. 
(c) Each PowerPoint presentation should be 12-15 minutes long. Members of every group must take turns making presentation within each oral presentation
